EPA RMP EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Accidental Release Prevention Policies at the Martinez Catalyst Plant (MCP)

The Martinez Catalyst Plant (MCP) is part Shell Chemical LP and CRI.  MCP is committed to being a responsible member of the Martinez and greater Contra Costa County communities.  We place a high priority on operating our facility in a safe, healthful, and environmentally sound manner.

Shell and CRI requirements dictate that their facilities continually identify methods to reduce the use of hazardous materials, evaluate risk, and reduce the risk to the community and environment through implementation of process design, engineering controls, and safe work practices and procedures.  This commitment to healthy, safe, secure and environmentally sound operations is documented in the Shell HSSE (Health, Safety, Security, and The Environment) Commitment and Policy.  The MCP Risk Management Program (RMP) is incorporated into this HSSE Commitment and Policy through the MCP Health, Safety, Security, and Environmental Management System or HSSE-MS.    Specific Plant RMP-related action items are identified, evaluated, resourced, and checked via an internal action tracking tool.  These documents, as well as other related materials are readily available to all workers.

MCP practically stresses safe, healthful, secure, and environmentally sound operations via an annual employee training program, various safety meetings, the Plant HSSE Committee and the Social Performance, Employee Activities, and Recognition Group (SPEAR) MCP has a Health, Safety, Security, And Environmental (HSSE) and Administrative Procedures Manual that comprehensively covers various aspects of management systems conformance.  Each employee and field contractor at MCP also receives a Basic HSSE Requirements Handbook.   Shell also maintains internal HSSE Audit and Management Review programs under its HSSE-MS.  Plant, Corporate, and contract personnel conduct internal audits at various time intervals (w

eekly to once every 3-5 years).  Management reviews occur continually throughout the year and at least annually.

A Description of The Martinez Catalyst Plant and The Regulated Substances Handled.

The Martinez Catalyst Plant consists of 2 main batch processes: Ethylene Oxide (EO) Catalyst and RM-17.  The EO Catalyst Process produces a silver-based catalyst that is sold to industrial customers that convert hydrocarbons to ethylene oxide.  A specially formulated impregnating solution is produced at the Plant and absorbed onto carrier pellets to make the EO Catalyst products. 

The RM-17 product is manufactured by reacting a proprietary raw material (containing toluene as a carrier) with a heavy olefin in the presence of a liquid catalyst.  A series of simple distillation steps removes the lighter boiling components (including the toluene).  The purified product is then shipped to other Shell Chemical facilities for further use in the process of manufacturing detergent products.

Accidental Release Management System Program/Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Management System

The Martinez Catalyst Plant has developed a formal Risk Management system based on CCPS Plant Guidelines for Technical Management of Chemical Process Safety and Shell HSSE-MS requirements.  This system is designed to plan, organize, implement and control the risk management program elements.  This management system satisfies the requirements of Section 2735.6 of the CalARP regulation (and EPA equivalent) and ensures that the risk management program elements are developed and continually improved.  Records associated with the prevention program elements are retained for a minimum of five years unless otherwise specified.   The management system activities are further discussed below.

¿	Planning - The Martinez Catalyst Plant has an overall HSSE program policy that identifies the objectives of its HSSE programs.  

¿	Organizing - Individuals responsible for each risk management pr

ogram element are designated.  These general lines of authority and communication are illustrated in the Table below.  Written requirements are contained for each OSHA/EPA/CalARP prevention element in the MCP Written PSM Compliance Plan (located within MCP's written Injury and Illness Prevention Plan under Procedure HSE-002).

¿	Implementing - Each assigned OSHA PSM/EPA/CalARP focal point facilitates the implementation of their program element.

¿	Controlling - Members of management and the individuals responsible for each risk management prevention program element periodically conduct internal reviews or audits against the goals and objectives of the element.  Annually, the procedures are reviewed and recertified to ensure that they remain accurate and reflect the current practices. 

General Lines of OSHA PSM/RMP/CalARP Authority And Responsibility

¿	The Site Manager has overall management responsibility for the Cal-ARP Programs.

¿	The HSSE Manager oversees Cal-ARP compliance not otherwise delegated.  This person provides administrative and technical assurance over the MCP Cal-ARP program.  This person also assumes the lead role regarding PSM Management, Application, Worker Participation, Process Safety Information), Incident Investigation (shared with the Production Manager), Emergency Planning and Response, Compliance Audits, and Trade Secrets.

¿	The Production Manager assumes the lead role regarding Pre-Start-Up Safety Reviews or PSSRs, Hot Work Permits, and Incident Investigation (shared with the HSSE Manager).

¿	The Administrative Associate assumes the lead role regarding Operating Procedures and Training of Operating Workers.

¿	The Technical Manager assumes the lead role for Process Safety Analysis or PHA, and Change Management.

¿	The Plant Engineer assumed the lead role regarding Mechanical Integrity. 

Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The process safety prevention programs described in the following section represent integrat

ed administrative controls intended to ensure the safety of workers, the public, and the environment.   Many of these prevention programs (e.g., process hazards analysis or PHAs, compliance audits, incident investigation) result in the development and implementation of additional safeguards (e.g., administrative and engineering controls).  Those recommendations that are planned for implementation at the Martinez Catalyst Plant will be discussed in "Planned Changes to Improve Safety" Section. Those applicable safeguards that are in place and serve to help prevent, detect, or mitigate accidental releases of Cal-ARP regulated substances are summarized below:   

 
General Accidental Release Prevention Program for MCP

Process Safety Information

Process safety information (PSI) development, dissemination, and use is vital to the effective operation of a stationary source.  MCP personnel use information regarding chemical hazards, equipment specifications, and operating limits in daily and strategic decision making.  Accurate and complete information that is readily accessible to employees and field contractors is therefore a basic component of the OSHA PSM/EPA/CalARP prevention program.

Established practices made sure that the original PSI was compiled in conjunction with the initial process hazard analyses (PHAs).  These practices ensure that relevant PSI is maintained current via the management of change (MOC), pre-startup safety review (PSSR), and other (e.g., hazard communication, etc.) programs.  Hard copies of the PSI are maintained (in various forms) in the Operations Supervisor's Office and the Administration Building.  An electronic copy of much of the information is also available.  Personnel have access to PSI information on a 24-hour basis. Accurate PSI is maintained for the life of the facility.

The Martinez Catalyst Plant has compiled process safety information (PSI) that satisfies the regulatory requirements of OSHA PSM, EPA RMP, and Section

2760.1 of the CalARP regulations.  This information was compiled under the direction of the MCP HSSE Manager and specifically followed PSM/RMP PSI requirements.  Various technical resources (Process Engineer, Plant Engineer, Control Systems Engineer, Operations and Maintenance) made sure that the level of scope and the level of detail was appropriate to safe MCP operations.  This PSI enables personnel involved in the operation of the process to identify and understand the hazards posed by those processes involving regulated substances such as ethylenediamine (EDA). Appropriate personnel from the Martinez Catalyst Plant verify that the equipment complies with recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices.  They also verify that all equipment is designed, maintained, inspected, tested, and operated in a safe manner.

Process Hazard Analysis

By systematically examining and identifying process safety hazards associated with the operation of a covered process, the Martinez Catalyst Plant has been able to plan and take appropriate action to improve the safety of our workers, the community, and the environment.  MCP has performed a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) covering the EO Catalyst Process every 5 years since 1999, with the last one conducted in 2014. 

¿	Identify hazards.

¿	Identify credible human errors and/or equipment failures that could lead to an external event.

¿	Evaluate the likelihood and/or consequence of various scenarios.

¿	Determine if existing chemical specific prevention steps/controls are adequate, and, where existing controls are inadequate, identify additional steps that can be taken to control the hazard.

In accordance with Section 2760.2 of the CalARP regulations, the Martinez Catalyst Plant consulted with CCCHSD and determined that the guideword Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP) methodology was the approach best suited for the PHA of the EO Catalyst Process.  This methodology was chosen due to general Shell pra

ctice and the opinion that HAZOPs provide an acceptable level of analysis detail.

The following objectives were addressed by the HAZOP:

¿	Identification of the hazards of the substance and of the process.
	
¿	Identification of the applicable external events (including seismic- and security-related events) that could lead to a release.
¿	Identification of possible equipment failures or human errors that could lead to a fire or release.
	
¿	Evaluation of the consequences and likelihood of the accident scenarios.
	
¿	Evaluation of the safeguards used to prevent or mitigate failures or errors.
	
¿	Consideration of the steps needed to mitigate the risks, including changes needed to equipment design, operating procedures, process conditions, etc.  A list of proposed (and prioritized) action items is then generated.

The HAZOP was conducted by a multi-disciplinary team that systematically identified hazards and operability problems by searching for deviations from the design intent of each portion of the process.  The team considered the causes and consequences of these deviations to identify hazardous conditions and their consequences, listed existing safeguards, and made recommendations for changes where appropriate.  A similar team conducts the revalidation of the PHAs every five years. PHAs are also updated, as necessary, in conjunction with the RMP updates. This documentation will be maintained for the life of the Plant.

The HAZOP team was composed of qualified personnel including a team leader, a project engineer, a process engineer, an Operations Supervisor, and a Union-designated operator.  Other specialists (e.g., control systems engineer, corrosion specialist, unit inspector, etc.) were consulted as required.  As is the Shell expectation and practice, the team leader had training and experience in conducting HAZOPs, as well as a general knowledge of the process.

The team identified and evaluated hazards of the process as well as accident pr

evention and mitigation measures, and made suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when such measures are necessary.  The HAZOP was documented and finalized on worksheets containing a description of each process node and its design intent, a list of possible deviations, causes of deviations, consequences, safeguards, and required action items/investigations/questions for further study.  These potential deviations were risk-ranked using the Shell Risk Assessment Matrix or RAM.  Any identified action items are formally tracked using the AcuTrack or FIM software and resolved through the MCP HSSE-MS.  OSHA guidance is followed regarding issue resolution.

Seismic (External Events) Analysis

The Martinez Catalyst Plant is located approximately 3 kilometers from the Concord-Green Valley Fault (Type B) and approximately 18 miles from the Rodgers Creek Fault (Type A).  This is based on a review of the "Maps of Known Active Fault Near-Source Zones In California and Adjacent Portions of Nevada" prepared by the California Department of Conservation Division Of Mines and Geology. These two faults, particularly the Concord fault, create most of the earthquake concern at the Martinez Site.

According to the ABAG (Associated Bay Area Government) Liquefaction Susceptibility Map, the potential for liquefaction at MCP is very low.  Also, based on the 1994 UBC Seismic Zone Map of the United States, the Martinez Catalyst Plant is in Seismic Zone 4.  The ground surface at the MCP includes soils that have been disrupted, modified, removed, built over, or filled with crushed rock or other material resistant to weathering, such as blacktop (asphaltic compounds), concrete, or compacted gravel, sand, silt and clay.   Soil conditions are considered to be alternating layers of claystone, siltstone, and sandstone varying from dense to very dense.  Based on this information, the Site Coefficient is S1.  Finally, based on the geology of MCP, the potential for landsl

ide or settlement is minimal.

County guidelines were followed during the seismic assessment of the EDA storage tanks, the EDA charge pump, associated piping system and the Solution Preparation vessel.    These are the only pieces of equipment within the EO Catalyst Process that contain EDA.  The objective of the seismic assessment was to provide reasonable assurance that loss of primary containment of EDA would not occur as the result of a major earthquake.  In addition, the following additional design practices or standards were used by MCP to identify and minimize the risk resulting from seismic hazards:

¿	Guidance for California Accidental Release Prevention (Cal-ARP) Program Seismic Assessments, prepared for the Administering Agency (AA) Subcommittee Region I Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), and prepared by CalARP Program Seismic Guidance Committee.

¿	Guidelines for Seismic Evaluation and Design of Petrochemical Facilities, prepared by the Task Committee on Seismic Evaluation and Design of Petrochemical Facilities, published by the American Society of Civil Engineers (Latest Edition).

¿	California Building Code (1998).

¿	API Standard 650 (Latest Edition).

¿	Shell Internal Design Standards (DEPS)

The walk down inspection included a thorough assessment of the structural elements and non-structural equipment and components.  The inspection addressed: 

¿	Potential areas of structural weakness due to design or construction deficiencies.  This includes inadequate anchorage to foundations or support structures.

¿	Identification of damaged components.

¿	The overall extent of corrosion.

¿	Piping spans, flexibility, lateral support, and attachments to vessels.

Eichlaey Engineers performed and documented the seismic walkdown inspection at MCP in 1999 and 2004.  The PHA facilitator and the MCP Plant Engineer conducted and documented a walkdown inspection in 2009 and 2014. The persons conducting this review were licensed Californ

ia engineers with experience in the methodologies and earthquake engineering procedures presented in CalARP's Seismic Assessment Guidelines document.  

Findings were recorded on worksheets and with a digital camera with audio recording capabilities to insure a well-documented, complete walk-through inspection.  The assessment findings can be classified into four main categories:

¿	Unanchored or inadequately anchored equipment.

¿	Adverse seismic interactions.

¿	Piping with inadequate or questionable lateral and vertical support.

¿	Corroded and/or damaged equipment.

Findings from the 1999 report have been completed.  No additional findings were issued as a result of the recent 2004, 2009, and 2014 reviews.

Operating Procedures

Up-to-date and clearly written standard operating procedures and safe work practices ensure that all applicable personnel will run the Plant in a safe, consistent and prescribed manner. The Martinez Catalyst Plant developed a written operating procedures program, which satisfies the requirements of OSHA PSM, EPA RMP, and Section 2760.3 of the CalARP regulation.  These standard operating procedures (SOPs) ensure that written procedures/practices are developed, reviewed, implemented, and annually certified as reflective of current plant practice.  These documents are primarily accessed online, although hard copies (including emergency procedures) are maintained in the Administration Building in case of a power outage. They may be found within the MCP HSSE Procedures Manual and the Operations Takeover Manuals and are available 24 hours a day. .  Information contained in these procedures includes:

¿	Steps for each of the following operating phases: initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, start-up following a turnaround, and safe work practices (lockout/tagout, confined space entry, line and equipment opening, etc.).   The latter are covered by a P

lant-wide safe work permit system.  The appropriate safety issues are also highlighted on the permits.

¿	HSSE sections which provide a brief description of the acutely hazardous chemicals and the associated hazards; the engineering and administrative precautions (e.g., ventilation, personal protective equipment (PPE) used to prevent exposures); the control measures to be taken if physical contact or airborne exposure occurs, and control of hazardous chemical inventory levels; and,
	
In the operating procedures for the EDA portion of the covered process, there are no tables of safe operating limits (i.e., minimum and maximum pressure temperature, flow, composition) and consequences of deviating outside those operating limits. Neither is there a troubleshooting guide that explains the steps to correct or avoid the consequences of deviating outside the identified operating limits (including initiation of emergency shutdown) or a list of applicable safety systems (e.g., alarms, interlocks, emergency systems and shutdowns), their functions, and their set points. That is because these systems don't apply here. However, the above information is available for the rest of the EO Catalyst Process and the other unit (RM-17) at MCP. 

Operating procedures (including applicable check sheets) were prepared by technical and hourly staff based on a careful review of each operating mode, recognition of the hazards involved, and the appropriate standard sequence of safe operating steps.  These procedures are periodically reviewed and updated by staff and line personnel to reflect current practices.

The operating procedures (including applicable check sheets) are maintained current and accurate through regular review cycles, management of change (MOC) reviews, and annual certification by Operations.  The MOC procedure is also used to manage temporary operating procedures.  The MOC review is dependent upon the complexity of the change and is performed as described in the MOC

Procedure.

Training

The Martinez Catalyst Plant believes that employees who clearly understand how to safely operate a process can significantly decrease the number and severity of incidents.  Therefore, a thorough training program focused on specific operating procedures and safe work practices is a key element of an effective prevention program.   

The MCP HSSE Department has developed a written training program to provide employees (those involved with operating the process) with an understanding of the types and causes of potential incidents or deviations within the process, and the hazards associated with the process.  The training program also instructs personnel how to operate the process within safe operating limits, and how to handle potential emergencies.  The training program satisfies the requirements of OSHA, EPA, and Section 2760.4 of the CalARP regulation,  and is comprised of the following initial training, periodic refresher training, hazard-specific training based on MOCs, pre-startup safety reviews (PSSRs) and other activities, and documentation.  The main specific tools used for this purpose are the MCP Training Catalog and the Shell Open University software package.

Operators receive initial training in safe work practices and basic operating principles prior to assignment.  Specifically, these new operators receive an initial training and Unit Qualification program.  The operators receive training specific to the operations of each process once they are assigned to a process.  The training criteria are documented in job skill matrices that list the knowledge required (e.g., safe operating limits, safety system set points) and skills to demonstrate (e.g., emergency shutdown, lockout/tagout procedures).  Various means are used to verify competency, including written and oral examinations, demonstrations, and on-the-job training.  Documentation of the training, certifications, and background information is forwarded to and maintained b

y the MCP Administrative Associate/Learning Administrator.

Operating procedures are now in a checklist format. Hence, refresher training on these procedures is easily accomplished by the Operator using the actual document in the field. This was developed with employee consultation and allows refresher training to be conducted at a minimum of every three years. Training documentation and is provided through the Administrative Associate/Learning Administrator
 Detailed training may also be required as a result of a specific MOC or PSSR.  Line supervision is responsible for ensuring that the necessary training is conducted prior to implementation of the change to satisfy the MOC and PSSR program requirements of OSHA PSM, EPA RMP, and Section 2760.6 and 2760.7 (respectively) of the CalARP regulation.

Mechanical Integrity (MI)

A well-established mechanical integrity (MI) program ensures that equipment critical to process safety is fabricated to meet process specifications, installed correctly, and maintained in a safe operating condition.  It also allows maintenance employees to proactively identify and correct equipment deficiencies to avoid associated incidents and down time.   The Martinez Catalyst Plant has developed a mechanical integrity program, satisfying the requirements of OSHA PSM, EPA RMP, and Section 2760.5 of the CalARP regulation.  The mechanical integrity program applies to pressure vessels, heat exchangers, storage tanks, pumps, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, and any additional equipment deemed by Operations and Maintenance personnel to be important to safety (e.g., fire protection equipment, specific pieces of rotating equipment, electrical equipment, and process controls).
 
Equipment is Purchased and Installed in Accordance with Standards and Specifications. Shell maintains a comprehensive set of engineering standards for the specification, purchase and installation of pressure equipment, tankage, heat

exchangers, relief systems, piping, pumps, electrical equipment, instrumentation, and structures. Equipment that falls into one of these categories is specified in accordance with these standards by the Plant Engineer or the Control Systems Specialist; with input from Operations, the Process Engineer, and the Maintenance Supervisor as appropriate. Equipment is purchased by the Warehouse Clerk in accordance with the specifications and at the direction of the Plant Engineer or the Control Systems Specialist. Equipment is installed in accordance with the standards at the direction of the Plant Engineer or the Control Systems Specialist. The Pressure Equipment inspector, in accordance with plant inspection procedures, provides quality assurance for the purchase and installation of pressure equipment, tankage, heat exchangers, relief equipment and piping. Quality assurance for the installation of electrical equipment and instrumentation is provided by adherence to testing procedures developed by the Control Systems Specialist. 

Some of the non-pressure equipment in the plant is specially engineered for its service. Shell Engineering Standards are used for specifying, purchasing, and installing such equipment where applicable (for example, standards for electrical motors are applicable), but not all aspects of the equipment design and installation are covered by Shell standards. In these cases, the Plant Engineer and/or the Control Systems Specialist or an engineer working at their direction reviews equipment design.

Inspection of Pressure Equipment.  The Pressure Equipment Inspector is certified to API 510 (Pressure Equipment), API 570 (Piping), and API 653 (Tanks). This person inspects equipment in accordance with these recommended practices, as well as other PI equipment-specific recommended practices, Shell written best practices and MCP HSSE Procedures. The inspector maintains a record of each inspection and schedules future ones. Inspection documentation is m

aintained for the life of the equipment. The Plant Engineer reviews unusual inspection results. The Plant Engineer and Technical Manager work with the Pressure Equipment Inspector to assure that inspections are being completed as required, that documentation is completed, and that inspection results are considered in setting inspection intervals. Equipment that is deteriorated beyond acceptable limits is repaired or retired.

Written Maintenance Procedures. Written general maintenance procedures are contained in the HSSE procedures manual and are reviewed on a periodic basis by technical staff. These procedures outline the maintenance organization and maintenance work flow as well as address specific maintenance functions. Maintenance on most non-pressure equipment is performed in accordance with the original equipment manufacturer's instructions. Maintenance on some non-pressure equipment is contracted by the Maintenance Supervisor to service companies who specialize in maintenance of specific equipment.

Inspection and Maintenance Practices to Maintain Integrity of Structural Components. MCP vessel inspection procedures include requirements for inspection of structural components and fireproofing at each external inspection. Significant maintenance work has been completed on replacement of deteriorated fireproofing in the plant. 

Maintenance Employee Training- The Martinez Catalyst Plant develops and qualifies its maintenance personnel and provides training on its specific equipment and processes.carefully assesses each applicant for employment and only hires maintenance personnel with skills and knowledge pertinent to their required job tasks. The Plant  has access to documentation of skills training for maintenance and contractor personnel. Maintenance personnel are also provided with an overview of the process, the hazards associated with the process, and general safe work practices. The Administrative Associate/Learning Coordinator maintains initial and

annual training records including content of training, instructor, and means used to verify competency for maintenance employees.  Maintenance contractors provide applicable HSSE training records for their employees to MCP as necessary.

Records of maintenance work are stored in a computer program (SAP) that is linked to the purchase of parts. Inspection records and remaining life calculations for pressure equipment are stored in a separate computer program. HSSE procedures are available electronically on the local web site. 

Change Management

Process changes at MCP are sometimes necessary to address safety, environmental, and operational concerns.  A change made in one part of a process may have unintended effects on other parts because the process is an integrated operation.  These changes are therefore appropriately scrutinized before they are made to ensure the changes do not compromise the safety and integrity of the process and to avoid adverse effects to worker and public safety, and the environment.

The Martinez Catalyst Plant has developed a written Change Management procedure that satisfies the requirements of OSHA PSM, EPA RMP, and Section 2760.6 of the CalARP regulations.  This Procedure includes a form that requires specific technical and process information regarding a proposed change, as well as required authorization signatures.  This Procedure ensures that applicable changes to the following are properly managed:

Process and Operating Changes
¿	Temporary Process Changes
¿	Utilities
¿	Feedstocks
¿	Operating Procedures
¿	Kinetics and Process Chemistry
¿	Heat and Temperature Balance
¿	New Process Chemical or Alternate Supplier
¿	Key Process Parameter Limits (KPPLs).
¿	Staff Changes

Facilities Changes
¿	Deferred Maintenance
¿	Equipment and Piping
¿	Instruments
¿	Materials Changes
¿	Temporary Bypassing of Equipment
¿	Temporary Bypassing of Protective Instruments
¿	Temporary Facilities
¿	Temporary Repairs
¿	Structural

¿	Pressure Relief or Venting
¿	Fire Protection or Emergency Systems
¿	Removal of Facilities from Service
¿	Change in Project Scope or Design

This Procedure does not apply to "replacement in kind" which is defined as replacements that satisfy the design specifications.  This Procedure also does not apply to routine maintenance. The full  Change Management process at MCP is covered within Procedure HSE-100 (Section D)

The Supply Chain Coordinator tracks the MOC records and recommendations under the overview of the Technical Manager. The Technical Manager also maintains the MOC records and documentation of completion of the recommendations for a minimum of five years.

Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)

The Martinez Catalyst Plant is comprised of 2 OSHA PSM or EPA RMP processes.  Modifications to these processes are sometimes required to improve safety and operability.  When these modifications require a significant update to process safety information (PSI) or if it is a new process, employees formally verify that all controls (engineering and administrative) are installed and implemented prior to startup.  MCP has developed a written pre-startup safety review (PSSR) procedure and specific checklists that satisfy the requirements of OSHA PSM and Section 2760.7 of the CalARP regulation.  

This Procedure confirms the following prior to the introduction of regulated substances:

¿	Construction and equipment is in accordance with design specifications;
	
¿	Safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate;
	
¿	For new processes, a process hazard analysis (PHA) has been performed and recommendations have been resolved or implemented before startup;
	
¿	For modified processes, the requirements contained in the written management of change (MOC) program have been met; and,
	
¿	Training of each employee involved in operating the new or modified process has been completed.

When changes in covered processes are ide

ntified or planned by Plant personnel, they must assess whether a PSSR should be performed.  This assessment is conducted as part of the written MOC and PSSR procedures.  In addition, appropriate personnel (e.g., Production Manager) review capital projects to ensure that PSSRs are initiated when new or significantly modified covered processes are installed.  

The PSSR checklists were developed to facilitate the PSSR and to document that all of the requirements were addressed prior to the introduction of various hazardous substances. Operations, Maintenance, Plant Engineering, and Process Engineering ensure that the following steps are taken prior to startup:

¿	A review of the design specifications is conducted for the new or modified equipment and construction.  These design specifications are verified against the equipment specifications documented in the written mechanical integrity (MI) program, and the design codes and standards and generally accepted good engineering practices all included in the PSI element.  

¿	The safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are revised or developed as necessary.  This is conducted in accordance with the written operating procedure, mechanical integrity, and emergency response elements. 

¿	For newly constructed processes, the piping and instrumentation diagrams (P&IDs) are complete and a process hazard analysis (PHA) is performed.   The recommendations from the PHA must also be resolved or implemented prior to start-up.  

¿	For modified processes, the P&IDs are updated.  The recommendations previously formulated during incident investigations, compliance audits, and PHAs are reviewed to determine the effects of the modification.  

¿	If employee (e.g., operators and individuals performing routine and non-routine tasks) job tasks will be affected, training is conducted in accordance with the training and other PSM elements.

The appropriate personnel review the completed PSSR documentation and p

erform a physical walk-through inspection before authorizing startup.  The Production Manager tracks the PSSR records and documentation.  PSSR records and documentation of completion of the recommendations are maintained for a minimum of five years.

Compliance Audits

The Martinez Catalyst Plant believes that ensuring that the PSM/EPA/CalARP prevention program elements are functioning properly (i.e., that they are complete, current, and applied in compliance with company policy, regulations, and good process safety practices) is vital to the continual improvement of the process safety and HSSE prevention programs.  Personnel perform internal compliance audits at least every three years to review and evaluate the written documentation/records and implementation of the prevention program. These audits are expected to last approximately 1-2 days.   Potential areas that can be improved within the prevention program elements are identified and recommendations are formulated and implemented to ensure an effective and improved overall prevention program.  The developed compliance audits program satisfies the regulatory requirements of Section 2760.8 of the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) regulation and the OSHA and EPA Process Safety Management Standards.  PSM/RMP/CalARP Compliance audits were conducted and certified in 1995, 1998, 2000, 2003, 2005,2008, and 2011.

A PSM/RMP Compliance Audit team for MCP will consist of one or more qualified HSSE personnel, any necessary technical staff resources, plus one or more designated Union representatives that are knowledgeable in the processes being audited.  The Audit Leader is currently the HSSE Manager who has multiple health and safety-related certifications (CIH, CSP, and PE) and has received specific Auditor's training in ISO 9001, ISO 14001, OHSAS 18001, and the Shell HSSE-MS. The Union representative(s) will be chosen by the Union (subject to confirmation by MCP).  The Audit protocol will be based

on OSHA Instruction CPL 2-2.45A CH-1 (PSM Program Elements) or similar Checklist, Shell Audit Guidelines, County input, and the results of previous PSM/RMP findings.

Audit Team member develop a list of recommendations for improvement.  The results of the compliance audit are then communicated to interested personnel and contractors via established Plant communications channels (including the MCP HSSE Committee).  The HSSE Manager then reviewed the recommendations, determined the appropriate resolution of each recommendation, and assigned responsibility for each recommendation.  The HSSE Manager is also responsible for compiling periodic status reports for the recommendations and maintaining the associated records.  Recommendations are tracked to completion. 

Incident Investigation

The Martinez Catalyst Plant believes that incident investigation is vital to the overall OSHA PSM/EPA/CalARP prevention program.  MCP has developed an incident investigation procedure that satisfies the requirements of OSHA PSM, EPA RMP, and Section 2760.9 of the CalARP regulation.  Its purpose is to investigate each incident that resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in a release of EDA or any other acutely hazardous materials that could have caused personnel injury or major property damage.  Personnel identify underlying cause(s) and develop and implement corrective actions to prevent reoccurrence of the incident, or similar incidents.   A proximate cause analysis is performed for significant incidents (e.g., onsite fatality, significant offsite health effects). 

Plant management has stressed to employees the importance of reporting all PSM and other near-miss situations.  A PSM near miss is an incident that could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release.  Employees are reminded that the proximate cause(s) of minor incidents and PSM near misses could result in major incidents if uncorrected.  Employees are encouraged to report minor incidents and PSM near m

isses to Supervision or HSSE either verbally, in writing, or anonymously.

The Site Manager or Production Manager determines whether an incident investigation is warranted and charters a team to do the work.  MCP uses root-cause methodology and analysis and applicable employees are appropriately trained.

A person trained in root cause techniques (e.g., TOP, TapRoot, 5-Y, Tripod, etc.) assumes the position of incident investigation team leader when an incident occurs.  The number of and experience of the team members is dependent upon the severity and complexity of the incident.  Typically, the incident investigation teams are comprised of a team leader, an expert in the process, and other employees (including contract employees as applicable) knowledgeable in the operation, design, and maintenance of the process. The incident investigation team leader is responsible for initiating the investigation as soon as possible, but definitely within 48 hours of the time of the incident or PSM near miss.  

The incident investigation involves four stages: 

¿	Gathering evidence (involves interviewing witnesses, taking photographs, collecting evidence and records, and obtaining samples as applicable); 

¿	Analyzing the evidence (also involves identification of root cause if a root cause analysis was performed);
	
¿	Developing conclusions; and
	 
¿	Formulating recommendations

The incident investigation team prepares a written report at the conclusion of the investigation that includes a completed 5-Y spreadsheet, required FIM information, or other applicable information. 

Employee Participation

The Martinez Catalyst Plant relies on the expertise of employees (including hourly and contract employees when appropriate) at all levels and disciplines to optimize operations and safety.   This is achieved by consulting with (i.e., exchanging information with, and soliciting input and participation from) personnel to ensure consideration of their knowledge and e

xperience in all applicable areas of the prevention program.    MCP has therefore developed a written employee participation plan (HSE-002)  that satisfies the requirements of OSHA PSM, EPA RMP, and the requirements of Section 2760.1 of the CalARP regulation.  The written employee participation plan (available in hard copy or through the local area network computer) ensures that:

Examples of participation include:

1.	Operations and maintenance employees being actively involved in the development of procedures; 
	
2.	Operations and maintenance employees being integral members of the established incident investigation teams; and,
	
3.	Operations and maintenance employees being consulted with regarding the appropriate type and frequency of training. 
	
¿	Employees and their representatives are provided access to PHAs, results of incident investigations, compliance audits and to other information required to be developed under the PSM/RMP/CalARP rules through the HSSE Department.

	The MCP HSSE Committee discusses employee participation issues as part of their periodic meetings.  Electronic copies of meeting minutes are distributed to each employee in the field.  Meeting minutes are retained for a minimum of 5 years.

MCP has developed a contractor program, satisfying the requirements of OSHA PSM, EPA RMP, and Section 2760.12 of the CalARP regulation, to ensure that safety issues are addressed during contractor selection and that owner and contractor owner share responsibility for the safety of all employees (including contractors).

wners and their performance at least as part of a quarterly PICS review.  The Site ensures that proper training is provided and documentation maintained for each contractor.  

Five-Year Accident History

The Martinez Catalyst Plant has compiled a five-year accident history for all accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.  The compilation of this information satisfies the requirements of OSHA PSM, EPA RMP, and Section 2750.9 of the CalARP regulation.  The five-year accident history allows MCP to explain to the community the factors causing or contributing to accidental releases, the onsite and offsite impacts of accidental releases, and the procedural and technological changes made to minimize the likelihood that this accidental release will not occur again.   The intent of this information exchange is to create an informed community while also documenting that accidental releases are investigated and concrete changes are made to protect against reoccurrence.  

During the 2014 PHA and the County Cal-ARP (1Q 2014), FIM incident investigation reports back to 2009 were reviewed. The objective was to identify  accidental releases of EDA that resulted or could have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.  No accidental releases of EPA or Cal-ARP regulated substances (e.g., EDA) were identified that met this criteria.
Emergency Response Program

Overall safety at the Martinez Catalyst Plant is governed not only by the ability to prevent accidental releases of regulated substances from occurring, but also by the ability to mitigate any accidental releases.  MCP has therefore implemented an emergency response program to minimize the effects o

f accidental releases on employees, the public, and the environment.  MCP's emergency response program is covered under contract with the broader emergency action plan/emergency response plan (EAP/ERP) administered by the Shell Martinez Refinery (SMR).  The SMR EAP/ERP provides a complete range of emergency response services to MCP including a full incident command system, the Auxiliary Fire Crew, a Hazardous Materials Team, a Confined Space Rescue Team, and an Emergency Medical Team (EMT).  In addition:

¿	Resources from the Petrochemical Mutual Aid Organization (PMAO) are also available through SMR.  PMAO is a CAER organization.

¿	MCP is located within the Contra Costa Fire District.  Resources from this public agency would also be available during an emergency.

¿	MCP is subject to the Contra Costa County Hazardous Materials Area Plan (Latest Addition).  Initial Agency Incident Response, Incident Command, and Incident Control would be expected to come from the California Highway Patrol (CHP) and/or the Contra Costa Fire District (or their designees).  The Contra Costa County Health Services Department Hazardous Materials Program Office (CCCHSD-HazMat) would normally be involved at the Incident Evaluation, Personnel Monitoring & Decontamination, Equipment Monitoring & Decontamination, and Public Safety & Information Stages.  Contra Costa Fire would arrange for any additional mutual aid resources under Management of Escalation.

The written EAP/ERP was previously submitted to CCCHSD under the Hazardous Materials Business Plan program.  This plan satisfies the requirements of Title 8 California Code of Regulations (T8 CCR§3220); the Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) regulation T8 CCR §5192l; and Section 2765.1(b) of the CalARP regulation.

The EAP/ERP for SMR/MCP includes employee evacuation routes, headcounting procedures, and training for employees.  This EAP/ERP also includes a notification list that provides the telephone nu

mbers of agencies and individuals to contact in the event of one of several pre-identified emergencies (e.g., fire, employee injury, and employee fatality).  The agencies and individuals represent local emergency responders (e.g., Fire Department), public notification and regulatory reporting requirements (e.g., CCCHSD), and internal notification (e.g., Site Manager, Corporate Headquarters).  The notification list requires that designated personnel make the notifications and document when the telephone calls were placed and the name and position of the person contacted. Completed "Notification Matrices" are maintained for five years.     

MCP uses basic fire fighting equipment such as fire extinguishers, hose reels, and fire monitors, as it's chemical-specific mitigation equipment at the MCP Site.  Various personal protective equipment (e.g., chemical-resistant clothing, fire bunker gear, SCBAs, other respiratory protection, etc.) are also readily available.  Properly trained employees can then respond to incipient fires (after notifying SMR of the emergency).  Specifics regarding fire brigade training and advanced chemical-specific mitigation equipment (e.g., fire trucks, foam tenders, HazMat Team gear, etc.) are available through the Martinez Refining Company.

Members of the SMR Health and Safety Department, Auxiliary Fire Crew, and/or the Response Actin Team (RAT) periodically conduct familiarization tours or table top reviews of the Plant facilities.  A representative of the Contra Costa Fire District also inspects the Plant periodically.  Regular "red tag" or field simulation drills are conducted in the field to test operational response. 
A periodic emergency drill is also conducted by SMR in conjunction with various outside agencies.  As appropriate, SMR, MCP, and/or the applicable emergency response agencies work together to resolve the given scenario.   This pre-planning activity ensures that the members of the responding agencies are familiar with S

MR/MCP facilities, the hazards of various extremely hazardous materials, the resources available at SMR/MCP and their location.  It also clearly identifies the capabilities and limitations of each responding agency. Copies of the drill records, including recommendations and critiques, are maintained at SMR and/or MCP.
   
The Martinez Catalyst Plant will also work closely with Contra Costa County Health Services (CCCHSD) regarding any necessary response to hazardous material releases, to assist in determining any downwind air monitoring, and to alert the public of the accidental release of EDA. SMR/MCP worked with CCCHSD to establish Telephone Emergency Network System zones that will be notified of the incident through the Community Warning System for any Level 2 or 3 incidents.  

The emergency response program, including the EAP and the ERP, is reviewed annually to ensure that it remains accurate and current.  Employees are trained on the emergency response program when initially hired, when the emergency response plan is revised, and when employees' responsibilities are changed.   

In addition, MCP workers receive a site-specific HSSE overview training on an annual basis.  This orientation covers site-hazards, process safety basics, and emergency response program issues.  The later includes emergency notification, emergency access, muster points, shelter-in-place, and possible evacuation routes (egress).  This orientation is repeated annually.  This training includes a video and issuance of the MCP Basic Safety Requirements Handbook.  Employees who have completed MCP-specific training are annually provided with an identification sticker for their hard hats.

Accidental Release Scenarios (Worse Case and Alternative) for EDA

Worse-Case Scenario

The worst-case scenario (WCS) for the Martinez Catalyst Plant is the release of total contents of 10,000 gallons (approximately 75,950 pounds) of ethylenediamine from Tank 390 or 391.   Credit was taken into account for the berm surrounding Tank Farm A (where Tanks 390 and 391 are located).   This is a passive mitigation measure. The results for the WCS were generated from the EPA RMPComp program at <0.1 mile or 528 feet. 

The population impacted by this scenario includes the Union Pacific Laydown Yard, the National Tree and Garden Company Staging Area, the Waters Moving Company (all located on Bridgehead Road within the Martinez City limits), part of the Tesoro AMORCO Wharf, and possibly the Cal-Trans Toll Plaza and parts of the Shell Martinez Refinery (SMR).  

Alternative Release Scenario

To assist in emergency response planning, this facility developed Alternate Release Scenarios.  ARS results are useful for assessing the potential hazards posed by a facility and developing or assessing emergency response plans to respond to such an event.  This type of scenario is unlikely to occur, but is physically possible and reasonably feasible.

The ARS chosen was a possible release of EDA from a 2" line being severed downstream from the transfer pump, resulting in at least a 10 minute release of approximately 2800 pounds or 350 gallons of EDA.  Ten minutes was the time determined for the release to be detected, the system remotely isolated, and the pump shut down upon detection of the leak. This scenario was chosen through consultation with MCP Operations and Process Engineering.  It is considered to be the worse credible scenario associated with the batch handling of EDA.  Mitigation systems included the following:

¿	Deluge system (fire monitor). 
¿	Remote isolation of transfer pump suction valve upon indication of release; and
¿	Remote shutdown of transfer pump upon indication of release.

The results for the ARS were generated from the EPA RMPComp

program at <0.1 mile or 528 feet. The population impacted by this scenario includes the Union Pacific Laydown Yard, the National Tree and Garden Company Staging Area, the Waters Moving Company (all located on Bridgehead Road within the Martinez City limits), part of the Tesoro AMORCO Wharf, and possibly the Cal-Trans Toll Plaza and parts of the Shell Martinez Refinery (SMR).  

Mitigated Release Scenario

One way to effectively mitigate the effects of the ARS would be to flood the area with water using existing fire monitors and hose reels.  The amount of EDA released to the atmosphere would be reduced by a minimum of 90% (the calculated efficiency of a water curtain). These distances resulting from this mitigation would probably still reach a public receptor (see above) at <0.1 mile or 528 feet.
